> The diff coverage is `100%`.

+1 LGTM
lgtm
Please fix your branch
Can you give some screenshots?
If it looks good, can we merge this in @AllisonWang @aoen
LGTM
thank you!
@aoen this PR can be closed as well. Just letting you know.
I can't close it unfortunately @deckmon will need to close it.
Ah got it @aoen. Just was trying to get rid of old PR's for your team. But no problem! @deckmon you can close this ticket and the JIRA ticket for it, AIRFLOW-1239.
Thank you for contributing :)!
Addressed comments @saguziel , will do a final round of testing the alembic migration plus the xcom logic on our staging cluster after a LGTM.

Not sure if this is the right place for this comment, but I also noticed that using TimeSensor under python3 naturally also doesnt work since it imports the sensor module, hdfs and the other stuff gtoonstra mentions above.

I havent looked at the code but starting a job on time shouldnt have any dependencies on HDFS. :)

It would probably be good to look over the code base and refactor things a bit so snakebite is only imported in the actual hdfs related modules. This would make airflow a lot more compatible with Python3 by default.
@sdiazb, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @skudriashev, @artwr and @jlowin to be potential reviewers.

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2526?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [4ce2502...18fcecc](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2526?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

Codecov is stuck.
https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/551c83b6bc2ca97d0c820bc86d028df930fd4290/build

The problem is we have
`airflow_run local` -> `airflow_run raw` -> `task` in terms of process hierarchy.

The local process kicks off the raw process, and then heartbeats periodically, and decides whether or not to kill the task (one example of why it might do so is if the state in the DB has changed)

The raw process checks dependencies, sets the DB state to running, runs the task, then reports success or fail to the DB.

The task is the actual work being done.

The issue is when the local process does the heartbeating, it checks that the state is running, otherwise it kills the task since that means the state was changed externally. However, since the state change happens in a separate thread, we are not sure when it happens. If we assume that the state has already been changed, we will be wrong most of the time. So, the local process keeps a variable called `is_running`, which is set to True iff the heartbeat sees the task in the running state. However, it may never see the task in the running state since it polls the DB (not receives events). 

An example is that a task could be run, and the state could be cleared in the UI before it heartbeats. Now, is_running will never change to True, and the local process will never do the state check. Thus, in this case, the state will be cleared, but the task will continue to run indefinitely.

The other real solution is interprocess communication which is kind of messy, especially when we have different layers due to bash and such. Realistically, the heartbeat process should just be in a multiprocessing thing, but it's a bit hard to refactor now, so if we do decide to go on that route eventually, this is a good first step. This solution of putting the state checks into local is the smallest refactor that doesn't become too large. It's feasible to refactor more of this later, but it is definitely too much for 1 PR, and has questionable value in my opinion.

This doesn't look too useful because in most cases you probably won't keep around all virtualenvs because of disk usage. With wheel caching, virtualenvs can actually install pretty fast. (for example, airflow cached, with 100 deps, takes a few seconds)
thanks

Does recovering the queue actually get us much? I can see how it would be useful in the future, but it's probably more important to recover the `jobs` table which has LocalTaskJobs since this has the job heartbeat logic.
I think it's pretty safe to double queue tasks as long as it isn't too frequent, but restarting the scheduler can cause running tasks that died to not get restarted

    ImportError: No module named flask_appbuilder
Overall, LGTM. Following the approach we discussed taking, so no real surprises, which is nice.

There was some discussion before about moving the webserver out into it's own python package (that talks to the airflow core over the API). Unless we can somehow make www2 work like www does now cleanly by default then I don't feel super great about having to maintain both www and www2 so maybe this is the right time to flesh out the API and create this separate package. For what it's worth I definitely see Airbnb (and other companies) switching to this (or something similar) in the future, in this case we(AirBnB) could only help support the www2 model and others who still wanted to use the old www model could support that one.

I think this bug might actually be larger than just json -- setdefalt() will die with the same error even if JSON isn't used.

@gwax @saguziel This is a working implementation. The 'running' state of the executor is re-instated after a restart. I could also do the same for queued_tasks which would reinstate the whole state of the executor after a restart, effectively closing the gap that we have between executor and scheduler (tasks are set to QUEUED when moved to the executor, but there is a delay (ie. heartbeat) before it is send to the MQ thus a kill leaves a window in which a QUEUED task can get lost).
